I have worked with the most amazing and resilient people, doing the best they absolutely can in the circumstances highlighted below. 
Workplace flexibility is great.

Most siloed and hierarchical organisation I have come across where bullying is accepted at the top and trickles down the directorates. 

Macmillan has a big challenge ahead of itself to tackle an organisational, structural and systematic culture where belittling and marginalising is common practice - and another restructure will simply not solve those challenges magically. 

Executive and programme level decisions are made without evidence and without a true understanding of the front line’s work. Senior Leaders are completely out of touch with their teams and yet make decisions impacting them without truly understanding the operations they lead - because “you’ve been there” a while back does not mean you still get it. 

HR will say that they “don’t tolerate bullying” but seems to be a weapon used by Senior Management and contribute to the sense of bullying and complete lack of transparency. This reinforces a culture of deep mistrust. 

No competency in change and programme management with year long programmes delivering nothing but “interim” and minimum viable” products. 

A shame as it seems like an organisation which has completely lost itself, and its purpose.

It's hard to see poor decisions made without the right people being consulted, knowing it will hurt people with cancer in the end.  


More and more jobs (and powers) are being centralised in London, despite Macmillan saying it understands and respects devolution in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland , and the increasing devolution in England. job_title: Online Community Officer in London, England
pros:
Amazing working atmosphere with the colleagues closest to you. Everyone's very warm, welcoming and encouraging. Great social feeling to teams.
Know you're making a difference to people affected by cancer.
cons:
Management - appreciate your staff or lose their talent. In the space of six months, Macmillan's lost all three core members of its Online Community team - a service that supports hundreds of thousands of people. Why? Through sheer disregard, disrespect and lack of support/resource. Such a shame.

Lack of career development. No appreciation that staff want to move upwards and onto bigger, better roles.

A 'recognition/rating scheme' for objectives that was/is pointless - gold-star rated staff members that aren't rewarded for their consistent hard work, just told to 'keep going'.

Way too much change at one time, bringing down morale and making staff suspicious of upper management. Added pressure and stress. The only thing that got me through the last few months was the people around me.

pros:
Trusted Brand
Some lovely people to work with
cons:
Senior management
Lack of diversity
Too much chop and change

pros: Great to work for such a great cause.  The people on the front line are amazing, and there are loads of great people behind the scenes too. Salaries aren't too bad for the sector. Great brand too, and it looks great on your CV.
cons: The executive team seem more interested in playing politics than showing leadership. The culture has changed following an influx of well-paid senior managers with corporate backgrounds. The organisation has gone downhill since the current chief executive took over. There's a lot of change going on, but none of it seems to make things better. A lot of this seems to come from the "technology" section who seem to have their own agenda. A lot of money seems to get spent on consultants and it can be quite demoralising, when you think where the money comes from.

review_title: Politics ruining what is otherwise an amazing company
job_title: Senior Web Developer in London, England
pros: Extremely friendly people, feels great to know you are working for such a good cause, HR really try their best to ensure employees are happy
cons:
Internal politics prevent the company from excelling at the rate it should due to the high rate of staff turnover.

An extremely discouraging culture of micromanagement exists amongst employees in positions of power. This includes means such as keeping spreadsheets to record the exact time that an employee leaves and returns from lunch and reporting them to senior management if they are not back within the timeframe. Other methods such as spying on computers screens during office hours to ensure employees are working is also an issue. One which ultimately lead to my resignation from an otherwise pleasant company

Lastly, the office in Vauxhall is a shambles (though this is to be expected from a not for profit charity)

pros: Made some good friends over the years.  There are some good people who mean well but unfortunately they’re in a minority.
cons:
The environment and moral is getting worse.  It used to be a great place to be but now it’s full of people who are incompetent, lazy, sanctimonious and not too bright, they really do pay peanuts for monkeys.  HR is full of idiots who don’t care about the well being of employees despite serious allegations brought to them, including sexual discrimination against men of which if any man makes a complaint they will brush it under the carpet and mark it as “Allegation not upheld”.  I have also seen many employee bullied out of a job.

Middle management are arrogant who constantly work from home and will find any excuse to not let their workers do the same.

Arrogant and useless IT directors who seem to know nothing about computing but expect you to work on an old 32bit PC that’s over 10 years old whilst insisting it has the latest software installed on it.  Hence the PCs constantly lag, hang and crash.

An overpaid CEO, on an inflated salary, that knows nothing about cancer and is more interested in the propaganda of cancer and her own image on TV.

pros: You're not working for some one elses profit. But to help people
cons: Where to start. There's a reorganisation going on. It's blatently clear that measures are designed to drive out staff with out having to fork out redundancies. Mgmt have just rebanded staff salary, but did an underhand trick of adding London allowance to your salary which was always treated seperately.  So now everyone is over band and subject to restrictions such as non penshionable parts of your salary and potential freezes of salary raises.  There is an endemic culture of bullying by management  which HR will not address. I know three staff members who were forced to resign after complaining about bullying. Where all hr wanted to do was to make complainants face the bullys in a room.  In fact hr has a really high turnover rate themselves.  They no longer promote internally they just hire people in.  And forget training.  It'll never get past the heads of level.  Yet they themselves seem to be on many courses...

review_title: Kind, passionate people working for a great cause
pros: Kind, supportive people and a strong sense of connection to a wonderful cause.   Great development opportunities and an excellent benefits package for the charity sector.   Although everyone works hard, work-life balance is still prioritised with a progressive approach to flexible working (for most people - more could be done to ensure this is the case for all).
cons: My own personal experience has been excellent, but Macmillan has grown a lot in recent years, and it has sometimes struggled to adapt to that growth - there are some laborious processes and outdated systems that need to be replaced.   Although we need to adapt to a changing external environment, there is an overemphasis on restructuring, and the restructures have been very damaging to morale in some areas.   Although equality, diversity and inclusion has been prioritised much more recently, it hasn’t yet led to a more diverse workforce (particularly at a senior management level).

job_title: Supporter Donations Assistant in London, England
pros: The work the charity does is imense, and it shows through the support people give back to the charity to keep it going on and helping more and more people.
cons: The management is terrible. I worked in the customer care department and our managment was absolutely terrible. Underqualified, uncaring and overdramatic managment is what I experienced, as did many I worked with. Additionally, there was too much office gossip and not enough of a  professional atmosphere encouraged by managment (who were aware of this). I also found it very difficult to get any recongnition for my work, extra hours or effort I put in. As mentioned in other comments, the younger/bouncier you were, the more likely you were to get any type of recognition or fast advancement. There was a clear hirachy and clear favourites in the office. I never felt I could be honest with my feelings/opinions or have them taken seriously. Lastly, career advancement opportunities are low and difficult to obtain, even internally.

pros:
Macmillan has a strong brand and the trust of the public and the healthcare system, which could be used to deliver great services.

There is a huge amount of experience within the organisation who, given the right support, could have the potential to develop great services with a huge impact on cancer services in the NHS.
cons:
Macmillan knows who it wants to support but does not have a clear sense of how the lives of these people will be improved and even less how this improvement might be measured.

The organisation does not have a clear strategy that is well understood by staff and therefore delivery reflects this.

The Executive team is utterly uninspiring and does not appear to be well aligned or organised.

Evidence for the services that are funded and delivered is patchy and the strategy to  change this is nebulous.

Macmillan has a good understanding of what patients want but absolutely no sense of how these desires can be aligned with how the NHS commissioners and delivers services.

Career progression is possible and promotion is typically from within however there is no comprehensive support for individuals and therefore the organisation does not get the best from people.

review_title: So sad to see this once great organisation failing.
pros: It was wonderful to work with such dedicated colleagues and help make a difference to the lives of people living with and affected by cancer - but the culture changed and I'm very glad that I no longer work for such a shabby organisation.
cons:
The management was terrible.
An appalling bullying culture took hold. Terrible communication of a lengthy change programme led to an incredibly stressful working environment. People were constantly in fear of losing their jobs. 

Unionisation was resisted, and no union was recognised - which continues to be the case. 

I'm sad to say that I saw several people, friends included, bullied out of the charity. I also saw managers celebrating getting rid of staff. I could never recommend this awful organisation to anyone. My experience was one of seeing a nasty corporate culture take hold, and little value placed upon long-serving, dedicated staff.

review_title: Started great, but soured towards end
pros:
- Macmillan's health professional really are amazing and incredibly nice.
- The public genuinely loves Macmillan.
- It can be exciting to work in such a big organisation.
- Good place to work in your 20s.
cons:
- Extremely hierarchical. There's an obsession with job titles. It can feel like you're expected to know your place.
- Not much of a meritocracy. Often saw extremely talented people passed over for promotion in favour of extremely untalented people (see reason below).
- There's a definite Macmillan-type (extroverted, well-spoken, bubbly, often young). If you fit this type, great. If you don't, it can be frustrating.
- The amount of money wasted and misspent was scandalous.

pros: The services provided to people living with cancer are amazing. The guys working at the coal face are the ones I have in my mind when trying to do my job.
cons: The leadership is broken. Imported from a corporate background, they have sucked the heart out of the back offices. Clueless, deaf to ideas from within, they blunder on in the foolish belief that anyone who has years of experience in the charity must be dinosaurs and disposed of. My colleagues and I are burned out and morale is at the lowest I have witnessed.

pros: Some of the junior research staff were friendly enough.
cons:
Environment of Bullying and Harassment.
There is no procedure implemented for employee wellbeing. 
 Concerns and complaints raised are not taken seriously or ignored completely (resulting, on a personal level, to deteriating health and increasingly desparate mesures to deal with it). 
 Management run an overtly discriminatory environment, where they play favourites, hold double-standards and discourage communication between colleagues. 
 Meetings would be arranged, and then completely ignored, Management not interested in resolving conflicts.
There is zero career development strategy or procedure. 
There were inappropriate comments and responses from Management regarding both myself (and my personal heath), and a colleague who was returning to work after a cancer diagnosis.
I witnessed dubious practices in regards to data protection and conflicts of interest. 
Be prepared to be ignored, lied to, insulted and humiliated.

job_title: Adviser in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Dedicated team of people trying to do their best for people affected by cancer. Good training generally and ok pay.
cons: Bullying line managers and ineffective HR who are not fit for purpose and resort to blaming the victims !

review_title: Has become drastically worse in the last 18 months
pros: The cause is an important one
cons:
A 'change process' lead by out of touch senior management and external consultants has been going on for the last year or so, and is destroying morale and preventing good people from doing their jobs and working to support people affected by cancer.
Having established itself as a leading charity brand, it seems Macmillan's leadership decided that the next step was to outgrow the charity sector altogether and become explicitly 'corporate' in its outlook and culture. 
There were genuine problems associated with the growth and success of the previous years (wasting money on too many projects and new hires with not enough oversight and governance) but the answer should not have been for management consultants and directors with no sector experience to concoct a restructure without bothering to try to understand people's roles and contributions. 
The result is rock-bottom morale, an aggressive and uncaring HR function and good people leaving in droves.

I would avoid working here until they sort this out.

job_title: Head of Finance in London, England
pros:
Passionate and friendly people who care about the cause
A relaxed working environment where people work their hours and can work flexibly if needed
Knowing that your effort is aimed at supporting people affected by cancer
cons:
It is a big organisation now but still has some of the traits of a smaller organisation; sometimes being about who you know; dated service functions (IT, Finance, HR etc.) that are still trying to get up to speed.
Peoples passion for the work means it can be a bit of a sensitive environment that is resistant to change.

pros:

review_title: Avoid like the plague if you seriously want to make a difference to people affected by cancer
job_title: Direct Volunteer Services Coordinator in Edinburgh, Scotland

cons: Still have nightmares at the way Senior and middle management bullied staff and spent their time in endless meetings achieving absolutely nothing. Macmillan has a set of values and behaviours they expect staff to embrace but fail completely to demonstrate they understand them at all in the way in which they conduct themselves. HR are hopeless too and are nothing but glorified administrators- unable or just disinterested in challenging the bullying culture that is rife in this organisation.

job_title: Fundraising Support Assistant in Norwich, England
pros: You help make a positive difference to people's lives
cons: It's infested with corporate types who think they're doing Macmillan a massive favour by taking a tiny paycut to join them. But the real reason they joined is because they couldn't survive in the corporate world. How do I know? Because they can't hit their targets to save their lives and they can't write a single email that isn't riddled with appalling grammar and spelling. My volunteers were worth 100 of them any day of the week.

review_title: Great company, just don't work in the IT department
job_title: Service Desk Analyst in London, England
pros: Fabulous company, great team spirit, very satisfying to know you are helping people affected by cancer. Some great colleagues with a good attitude. Inspirational chief exec.
cons: Working on the IT ServiceDesk is such a chaotic, demoralising experience. A real lack of standard processes and procedures, which leads to a poor quality of customer service, meaning low level of job satisfaction. We work very hard and try our best, but are thwarted at every turn by not having standards and proper processes. Also, unpleasant cramped, dated, badly-lit offices in London. Queuing for the lifts to a high floor in this busy building can make you late for work.

review_title: Staff don't matter which is going to impact the public
pros:
Flexible working
Good people (but they're being got rid of)

Hierarchical structure neglecting staff welfare, moral, and current restructuring process means vast wealth of skill, knowledge, hard work, dedication is being wiped out rapidly with no consideration to the future.

Moral at all time low

pros: Everyone I have met has been driven and engaged to make things better and drive the charity forwards. There is a lot of positive energy and everyone is really friendly. Salaries are actually great compared to other industries and whilst benefits could improve you'd struggle to find somewhere else that invests so much in their employees.
cons: There are a lot of negative reviews on here, most of which seem like they come from individuals going through change. I don't agree that there is a poor culture, I think there are a lot of change programmes going on and naturally with that comes unrest and some upset but Macmillan has to evolve to be fit for future and that means change to ways of working.

pros: Great Cause, nice colleagues, Early finish on a Friday
cons:

- Lofty but largely unfulfilled promises of career training and development.

- High turnover of staff means that it can be difficult to keep track of actions required to complete a project when those initially responsible have left.

pros: Great cause some really great people work here. Level of care and support given by a skilled workforce for cancer patients
cons: Bullying in the workplace accepted by middle and higher management . Staff turnover is concerning and senior manager must address this

cons: upper management changes have filtered down to their being no new work happening. no career progression, mostly fixing bugs and small changes. huge turnover of staff, anyone with ambition or desire to learn have left. taken on a junior dev and not given any guidance or support, was told that my expectation were too high by manager when I said I could learn more.

review_title: Good for the start of your career, less good for a serious career/development
pros: Most people are fun, well humoured and human. People really care about the work that they do. Informal attitude.
cons: Very poor leadership and management from senior leaders up. Many self-interested and competetive management styles, lots of anxiety, no feedback, poor behaviours highlighted are not addressed, see support as a weakness, lack of integrity and big gap in clear relasonabilities and accountabilities. Poor management and HR support for issues.

pros: Working to support people affected by cancer rather than for shareholders. Some talented people who work really hard to make a difference.
cons: A lot of bullying in the workplace (could give 5 concrete examples of different people's experiences), high turnover of staff, lack of direction, management very much out to make themselves look good rather than take care of their team or individual needs. If your face doesn't fit they will manage you out. Not a huge amount of commercial acumen which would go a long way to make better use of supporter donations. Unwillingness to follow policy/corporate strategy due to fear of change.

review_title: Bullying and Harassment a common theme
pros: The purported values of the organisation are incredibly worthy.  There are a lot of good, talented people working there, who truly do want to do their best for people affected by cancer
cons: The number of grievances currently underway in mac by people who have experienced bullying and harassment by managers, is quite staggering.  Rather than do something about it, HR and legal are fighting the people who are complaining.  I would be interested to know how much money has been used from the coffers to pay these people to keep quiet? After all, it is publicly donated money.  I would also be interested to know how you treat people once they have raised a grievance? I will share my story soon

pros: Shorter working week, flexibility in hours (when approved)
cons:
I've been working for Macmillan a good while, and the past few years have shown a rapid decline in overall morale. 

The management culture is bullying, deceitful and back stabbing. Some of the managers also show no leadership or support to their staff, and often take them for granted by following their own personal agendas rather than the good of the company.

There are however happy to gang together when they feel their leadership is questioned, and quick to stifle anyone who dares to speak up.

For a charity who prides itself on empathy and support for cancer sufferers,  it's seriously lacking any towards its own staff.

review_title: A corporate bullying world wrapped in charity paper
pros: Good learning and development package. Good benefits and good knowledge
cons: Bullying often goes to alot higher than staff can reasonably take matters. Bullies often go un noticed and belittle those with good ideas. Nowhere to turn if bullied and policies allow for bullies to always win. There is a definite Macmillan type and if you dont fit you will be pushed put either little opportunity to move and made to feel that you cant do your job. Often decisions are money based and nothing to do with people living with cancer.

pros: People are generally friendly, apart from some of the  management.  The work hours are good.
cons:
Hard work is not recognised unless you are cliquey with management.  Lack of proper direction and focus despite hiring numerous managers to do exactly that.  Lack of career progression, often stifled by management and the HR experience which is terrible. The current HR representative for my department is just awful, no respect and has a don't care attitude.

New hires don't understand charity culture, often alienating many parts of the business and staff with their attitude.

It's a dog eats dog culture now in the London office, once upon a time you felt like the charity and management actually cared.

pros:
The other people, both staff and volunteers, are fantastic - hugely caring and determined. 
A growing organisation that feels very positive.
The cause is a great one and the organisation tries hard to connect the staff with the stories of people they've helped, which is incredibly inspiring.
Amazing to feel that your work has improved someone's life
cons:
As with all charities there's a lack of money so people often juggle multiple projects at once and there's been a lack of investment in eg IT tools in the past.
Going through a big period of change, which can be unsettling for some

pros:
Working to support people affected by cancer rather than make money for someone.

Relaxed environment has positives.

Have been some good people working there.
cons:
It's a large organisation with a rigid hierarchical structure and a lot of politics and practices that limit your ability to deliver your best.

Very siloed, clicky sub-environments within the organisation in places. So while it may be ok in one area there are severe problems in others. It's not consistent but some appear to treat it like it is.

High staff turnover and too much reliance on contractors, so there's little continuity and an ongoing "period of change" that's seen many problems getting worse rather than better for some time.

Related to the staff turnover is a problem I see with the skills and experience balance in some areas. It's a bad environment for someone to join for a less experienced position because you won't be developed or shown good ways of doing things. It's an appealing environment to people at the opposite end of their career who are less interested in learning new skills and like the relaxed environment they can have. The space between those is where the majority of the staff turnover has and will continue to happen.

Too many people stay long-term because it's comfortable for them and they see it as difficult to find a similar experience elsewhere. That's not what Macmillan needs, and probably not what individuals need either.

There have been numerous occasions where individuals have acted to try and protect their position in the hierarchy from what they see as threats to it rather than do what's best for Macmillan. That may involve something as simple as withholding information from someone else, or it can be much more than that.

Part of the management approach appears to be to try and make people comply, rather than identifying and acknowledging the root of real underlying issues. Politics really hinder that.

pros:

- Wonderful brand that allows for creativity
cons:

- Mixed leadership - some who are reluctant to change and move forward and others who push us to be innovative - hence a lack of clarity on goals
- Very large organisation so can be difficult to understand the different teams
- Under resourced in certain areas and over resourced in others which makes work delivery difficult

review_title: No investment in training and development
pros: A well and rightly respected national charity; people are always react positively when I say I work for Macmillan. I have lovely colleagues and a worthwhile role.
cons: There is little chance of advancement and minimal training and development if you are a member of the office or support staff. A stagnant salary and no service increments. Work life balance will depend on your role, and your manager.

review_title: Wish it could have been different
pros: The cause is undoubtedly a good one and it does have a brilliant external reputation meaning you do get impressive access to significant networks and influencers. Many of the people are v friendly and there are great people to work alongside, many of whom are bright, experienced and passionate.
cons:
The actual environment is so different to how you imagine it will be at Head Office, with office space that has to be among the least effective at creating a coherent or happy organisation. The office space may be more affordable and I understand why therefore the charity rents it, but it is creaking and really too hot in summer and too cold in winter. There were significant works on the Thames outside that sometimes caused the building to shake and yet HR never treated this as a health and safety issue or looked at how to promote rota- based or home working during these major works.
There are far too many constant changes to structures and arguably not enough clarity for incoming members of staff that this is the environment they are being introduced into. It caused me wellbeing issues. 
The directorate I worked in always struggled for a clear identity within an organisation that seems to be built around competing, not collaborative, directorates (at least at executive management level). Our Executive Director who was very popular and impressive seemed to go very quickly, and much of the directorate she headed is being reshaped. There may be some valid strategic reasons for this, but there is a question about the degree to which recruitment to that directorate should have taken place in the past two years, when its future seemed so badly in doubt.
It was such a shame as I really wanted it to be a positive experience.

pros: Flexible working arrangements available (e.g. 9 day fortnight)
cons:
No autonomy, 
siloed working, 
dated technology and software used,
development of skills non-existent, particularly with regards to software 
little appetite to introduce new thinking, 
very slow and bottleneck decision-making (no delegation to more appropriate members of staff to make decisions), 
teams lack having clear identities and visions, as a result team members teams do not understand their own roles or how these roles should work with others (e.g. governance and responsibilities are rarely understood),
change fatigue across large areas of the charity,
lack of trust in senior management due to poor communication and inconsistent decision-making
Hierarchical structure, bloated with middle management role

pros: I spent 6 years working at Macmillan Cancer Support and it has grown from strength to strength. I met so many amazing people, some of whom I consider close friends. I had the good fortune to have progressed during my career at Macmillan and  thankful to the opportunity to thrive.
cons: Recognition for hard work is amazing to have but with no real monetary rewards linked to performance, sometimes the recognition can ring hollow.

pros: Some people are great to work with, great brand and worthy cause, flexible working opportunites, training portal
cons: Poor career progression opportunities, too many meetings coupled with not enough meeting rooms. Terrible senior executive  team. Bullying is poorly managed and means it is never dealt with and continues....... such a shame as the charity will lose good staff. The bullying and lack of comms and constant changes creates a very poor working environment and low moral.

pros:

The people at Macmillan are really passionate about what they do and it was great to be a part of an organisation with so much going on - both in the sense of innovative fundraising initiatives and fantastic programmes to help people with cancer. 

Great work/life balance at the organisation. Lots of opportunities for progression.
cons: Sometimes it feels like the organisation is too big, it's almost impossible to get to know everyone.

pros: Within IT it was a fantastic atmosphere, Macmillan really did want you to succeed and the people I worked with were really nice.
cons:
As all charities some times decisions are made in the interest of short term money.
Sometime you do see people money wasted.
The events teams dominate all IT priorities because in their words 'they bring in the most money'

pros: Lovely people who care a lot about what they do. Easy to understand how your role helps achieve a very noble goal. Talent is nurtured and there are lots of good career opportunities. More forward thinking than most voluntary sector organisations.
cons: Although I like change, the amount of change feels excessive at the moment, and it results in stress and lower levels of engagement.

review_title: If ever there was a company where the internal and external brands were polar opposites this is the one!
pros: There is very little positive to say about Macmillan as an Employer.  There are some fantastic people who work there and for a time they will keep you going but don't believe it will match the external hype.
cons: If you join Macmillan because you believe it will be a great employer who has the patient at the heart of everything they do think again.  This was the case 5 years ago but over the past 3 years it has gone downhill rapidly.  It is all about how much money they can fundraise.  They are constantly restructuring. throwing money down the drain on hair brained schemes and recruiting into over paid non-jobs in London while cutting the funds to the front line.  They treat staff at best as a commodity.   Even colleagues with Cancer aren't treated with care or compassion.  Bullying from the senior team is endemic.  They profess to have espoused the Macmillan values and behaviours but these only apply to those at the bottom - and don't ever speak out as our senior manager pointed out - you can be open and honest as long as you don't say anything that anyone doesn't agree with and you do it 'behind closed doors'??  They are making poor decisions and don't listen to anyone inside or out once they have decided on a course of action.   If you want your career, dignity and mental health to remain intact then avoid Macmillan like the plague.

review_title: Lots of talented people but staff satisfaction massively varies across organisation...
pros: Flexible working, scope for impact, important cause
cons:
Hierarchy, poor communication of change, depressing office space

Massive organisation so working collaboratively is difficult. Because of size, I’m sure some teams are happy but my directorate was overwhelmingly unhappy.

pros: Working in cancer support is a good thing to do
cons: unhealthy workplace culture, bullying, secretive, anxiety provoking

review_title: Worst company I've ever worked for
pros:
Flexible working arrangements (depending on department)
Office was easly commutable for me
cons:
Working at Macmillan has been hands down the worst 2 years of my life.
I guess I justified staying there as long as I did because I liked to imagine that we are there to help people, and the cause behind the charity is one worth staying for. Oh dear, how I wish I'd left as soon as I realised what a miserable and horrible place this is to work for.

Senior management does not care whatsoever about their staff's wellbeing- there is no team morale, no support. When I started I was promised a development route as I was keen to progress and develop in my area, but my requests of this being honoured has been shut down repeteadly over the 2 years, saying "do not need training". I had no development plan with my line manager, despite of me asking for this.

The bullying is so apparent and common that it has basically became the normal behaviour.  Talking to my collegaues and reading the reviews here seems to suggest the same thing across the whole organisation.
I was eventually bullied so much that I had to go to therapy. My confidence was completely destroyed and I struggled to find the energy to look for another job as I felt that I was worthless- all thanks to my managers.

The London office is horrible and dirty, no meeting rooms available, the IT desperately needs updating.

There is no decision making process in place, nothing gets done on time and people don't take responsibility for their actions, but pass it down. (hence the reason why there's no decisions being made)

Macmillan basically has way too much money and don't know what to do with it because they don't care about their employees, therefore everyone is leaving as soon as they can. (Example: within a year, 13 people left out of around 40) Honestly, this company is a disgrace and I'm ashamed that I was part of helping them waste money for 2 years.

If you care about your professional development and your mental health, avoid this company.

Leadership culture - CEO inexperienced behaves as one amongst many, unable to lead, little to no knowledge of individual directorate financial and operational dysfunction and encourages silo working and promoting "fifedom's"; lack of disclosure of CEO salary or review; hubris has led to "renowned 4 year change programme" to recreate a mgmt blue chip consultancy model which is now not fit for purpose led to £5m+ on mgmt consultants, resembles NHS restructure and fragmentation 2012;The state of the current restructure demonstrates and exposes the lack of leadership and has led to huge staff turnover and mass redundancy at a cost to donors. poor accountability of spend; encourage to spend, spend, spend at year end.

Money money money - the use of funds to "pump" prime cancer services is being used to fund "fun" quality improvement projects with friends, little to no measurement is done on the investments made (new year, new budget mentality) and little impact is made to close the gap in cancer care for people, Macmillan serves those already served well. Macmillan has lost credibility with a range of partners, its CEO is inexperienced in handling senior relationships and openly described her role as doing "fun and fluffy stuff". 

Diversity a big challenge  -  BME staff paid less and not promoted (unrepresentative, snowy white peaks), disabled staff forced out (yes in a cancer charity); complaints not addressed; recruit "mates" with similar background, yes this was an actual campaign by HR; unpaid interns; bullying culture; poor career development for junior staff; mgmt heavy lots of layers; recruit ex-mgmt consultants with poor behaviours; poor support for carers for ppl with cancer who were forced to leave; overt misogyny displayed weekly in executive leadership team; discomfort and aversion in engaging with "ppl with cancer" across all leadership levels; acceptance of the status quo and apathy, people come and leave - check the retention figures, morale as bad as NHS staff, despite healthy compensation.

pros:
Good work-life balance

Flexible working
Some of the people are absolutely lovely and very passionate and clever
cons:
The countless restructures, cold and unapproachable senior management, apathetic managers and poor approach to staff wellbeing mean that the working environment in Macmillan is miserable. 

The office is practically empty because people are essentially fleeing the organisation. The environment is cold and sad. People barely talk to each other but there's lots of whispering about redundancies and the future of the organisation.

If you're under management level your chance of getting a promotion, unless somebody above you quits, are practically nil. For this reason, people rarely stay for longer than a year.

Siloed working to the extreme. Major gatekeeping of areas of work that make collaboration working impossible because people are so precious about 'their' remit, when they should only be interested in improving the lives of people with cancer.

The senior management is a total joke, the restructure has been a total failure and disaster and so have the communications around it. The result is a chaotic and tense working environment where you can't get anything done because teams aren't there one day to the next.

Harp on a lot about staff wellbeing but it's all talk and no action.

They talk a lot about equality and diversity but if you don't fit into the typical Macmillan type then you won't fit in. 

There used to be a good social scene but the horrible way in which senior . management have dealt with the restructure has desecrated morale and led to dozens of people leaving, so this doesn't exist anymore.

Seniors can work from home seemingly whenever they want but don't expect the same back if you are under management level.

review_title: Awful environment and massive waste in organisation
pros: It is a good cause and some of the frontline staff do a fantastic job, but very little else going for it
cons:
There are so many negatives, it's hard to know where to start.

A common theme in other reviews and something I certainly experienced was bullying; it appears to be rife across the organisation but little seems to be done about it, with those who are most responsible for the bullying being long-term employees who there is a fear of challenging as to not rock the boat.

The systems, technologies and facilities were incredibly outdated and in much needed investment and modernisation, so if you work with any form of tech or digital tools it is like stepping back in time 15 years.

The atmosphere is very cliquey, so if your face fits you may get on well and be able to coast through your job doing little more than the minimum, however, if not you're probably in for a bumpy ride.

It is common with charities, but there is a lack of willingness to make a decision and take any responsibility from anyone, so there are endless meetings and contradictory communications around something before anyone makes a decision, which usually ends up being the one that will have the least amount of responsibility or repercussions for the person making it.

I was incredibly excited to be joining Macmillan when I first started, as I felt that it was a fantastic charity doing some really great stuff. However, that enthusiasm was drained out of me within the first few months as a result of the culture and atmosphere of bullying, cliquiness and poor management. 

While it was incredibly sad to see the amount of waste in the organisation, as millions in donations are just poured down the drain supporting the current set-up and approach.

pros:
- Great co-workers.  I made friends for life
- Less pressure compare to startups, agencies and large corporations
- Amazing cause
cons: Based on my first couple of years, I would give them 5/5 without hesitation, but unfortunately things have changed dramatically since. In the past 4 years, the Technology department, particularly in the Digital team have lost 80% of their work force and haven't bothered to replace any of them. The amount of knowledge and personalities lost have been staggering. However, the directors and senior management kept insisting that millions of £ will be invested in the department. The mother of all lies that was! If you are an IT professional who is eager to learn new skills or wanting to progress in your career, then avoid this place like the coronavirus. Things were looking bleak when I left, but now things are desperate from what I gather from my former colleagues. The majority of senior staff have been DEMOTED, some have been made REDUNDANT and the worst of all, existing staff have been asked to submit an essay-type self-assessment document to HR in order to justify their worth for Macmillan, which must be very humiliating. Therefore, based on the current state of affairs, I will give them 1/5. However, Macmillan still is one of the biggest and most loved charities in the UK (and rightly so) and it has a potential to be great again, but that will never happen unless some smart people take over from the current, clueless leadership and management team.

review_title: Not the organisation it pretends to be
pros:
Good views from the office window.
A small handful of nice staff.
cons:
I have been through organisational change twice, the first time was at the same time my dad was diagnosed with brain cancer. When I told a director in my consultation meeting that the time Macmillan were due to make my role redundant was the same month my dad was due to die, he shrugged and said it wasn’t their problem. 

This organisation does not care about people who are affected by cancer, it’s driven by policy and rules rather than caring for the people it employs. I was forced to take a days unpaid leave for a dads funeral as my compassionate leave ended the day before (Christmas time is a very difficult time to fit in funerals). My dad died of brain cancer, so this should have been something they understood. 

I had a line manager who had very little interest in the work I was doing, two years went by and I didn’t have a written up development meeting.

As time went on and the loss of two family members within 3 months my mental health took a turn for the worse and after a period of time off work. On drs advice I should have had a phased return to work. I was offered half a day. They do not care.

Too much organisational change and very little understanding of the effect this has on moral and ability to deliver change that is needed for professionals and people affected by cancer. 

The organisational change is very short sighted and Macmillan will see that they have fallen behind other charities, for example removing the physical activity team and the money and cancer team. These are services that people need. 

Due to all the change, moral is very low therefore the office is a sad and depressing place to spend 8hours a day.

review_title: Extreme Bullying and Micromanagement of Hard Working and Devoted Staff!!!
pros: It all started with a great idea for a good cause...
cons:
... but ended up in being a health-hazardous workplace - stay away from this company, if you value your own mental health (!).

I have been working to a very high standard, as my fellow colleagues also agreed by giving me relevant feedback. Always maintained values, policies and relevant work practices at this level. - The management could not care any less, if you really supported a person who is facing one of the worst experiences and difficult times in his/ her life. What they only care about is to bring numbers up, their own brand and image, which does not correlate at all with what people might project into it, as well as making more and more money by fundraising and donations - all whilst working their staff to mental exhaustion and illness. 

When trying to raise this issue with my line manager, whom I trusted a lot, I got back-stabbed by this person in return. Although I then passed this on to another member of staff of slightly more senior position and this person agreeing with me, I got manipulated and harassed by my line manager. This person would from then on constantly bully me. When I brought this up to senior management, they sided all together and tried to intimidate me with their horrible mind-games. On my request for reasonable adjustments, I was not provided any of that - even though there were clearly resources available and this is being imposed by the government by several legal/ public Acts. Thy simply wanted me out and continued to bully and manipulate me; knowing that I was not coping well anymore and got extremely stressed because of their actions. - Most of the staff of many years left due to the bullying culture and severe control patterns/ micromanagement and since the 're-structuring' process it got even worse. 

Initially they appeared friendly and welcoming, only to turn the table without warning and pounce on you. 

I became very ill, which my doctor confirmed was the effect the dysfunctional dynamic of this workplace had on me. - Never before did this happen to me. I work now for another FANTASTIC employer within the same sector and I must say - what a difference! They value their staff and appreciate them a human beings and don't feel the need to regress and play terrible games with them.

Having decided to work for Macmillan Cancer Support was the biggest mistake of my entire life!!! - Stay away from this place!!

Even though one excels and gives 120%, there are no opportunities provided to really advance within the organisation. Also, one has to use up free-time for relevant work related tasks, as some time within the actual allocated shifts patterns was never ever granted, when requested. So one is literally forced to work in her/ his free time in order to satisfy the management and ridiculously calculated KPI' s and targets. - Forget about training - you'll never be able to realise attending even one course, even though other individuals seem to be on training all the time!

This review reflects my personal opinion.
